channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Woman Without a Country: Adopted at Birth and Deportable at 30
item.description: She grew up thinking she was American. When she realized that she wasn’t, her quest to fix the problem put her at risk of deportation.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan

item.title: As November Looms, So Does the Most Litigious Election Ever
item.description: Last week alone, three federal rulings set election parameters in three states. And scores of legal fights spawned by the pandemic are shaping who will vote and how.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vote-by-mail applications were made available along a march route as people gathered outside of the Minnesota Governor’s Residence weeks after the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Colleges Plan to Reopen Campuses, but for Just Some Students at a Time
item.description: To provide some semblance of the campus experience during a pandemic, colleges say large chunks of the student body will have to stay away and study remotely for all or part of the year.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard University said it would allow only 40 percent of its undergraduates to be on campus at a time — mainly freshmen in the fall and seniors in the spring.

item.title: Months Into Virus Crisis, U.S. Cities Still Lack Testing Capacity
item.description: With cases surging, some cities are seeing long testing lines and slow results.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tests were prepared at a drive-through location in Phoenix late last month.

item.title: In New Book, Trump’s Niece Describes Him as Still a Child, Seeking Attention
item.description: The release of Mary L. Trump’s “Too Much and Never Enough” has been widely anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.category: Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the Worlds Most Dangerous Man (Book)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Tuesday. His niece Mary L. Trump, is the first to break ranks with the family and release a tell-all memoir.

item.title: 2 People Charged With Hate Crime After Black Lives Matter Mural Is Vandalized
item.description: If convicted, the two residents of Martinez, Calif., could face up to a year in jail, prosecutors say.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Youtube
item.media:description: A couple defaced the Black Lives Matter mural in Martinez, Calif., on July 4.

item.title: International Students in Online Courses Face Lost F1 Visas, ICE Says
item.description: International students will be required to take at least one in-person class to keep their visas, at a time when many universities are prioritizing online instruction.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I realized that I might be deported back to my home country,” said Loay Alem, 19, an engineering student from Saudi Arabia who attends the University of California Los Angeles. “It was so absurd, so insane.”

item.title: Election Day in Paradise (New Jersey)
item.description: Today’s primaries are the perfect excuse to check in on our newsletter writer’s favorite state.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Emma Sanders, Southern Civil Rights and Political Activist, Dies at 91
item.description: She was one of the “unofficial” slate of Black Mississippians who sought to displace the nonrepresentative all-white delegation at the 1964 Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Wesley Ellis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Sanders at her Jackson, Miss., home in 2004. She became active in the civil rights movement after discovering that her son had already gotten involved.

item.title: W.H.O. to Review Evidence of Airborne Transmission of Coronavirus
item.description: The World Health Organization plans to update its advice after hundreds of experts urged the agency to reconsider the risk of aerosol transmission.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: John Locher/Associated Press
item.media:description: Gamblers in masks at a Las Vegas casino on Saturday. Scientists are increasingly concerned about indoor settings in which the coronavirus may linger in the air.

item.title: When Washington Helped Small Business, Washington Was Helped
item.description: The loan program to help firms keep paying their workers had many beneficiaries. Among them was the capital’s permanent political class.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets near the Capitol in Washington. Funds from the $660 billion forgivable loan program went to lobbying firms and other groups that make up the political industrial complex.

item.title: Eagles Receiver DeSean Jackson Apologizes for Anti-Semitic Posts
item.description: The Philadelphia Eagles condemned social media posts by Jackson, the team’s star wide receiver, saying they were “absolutely appalling.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Michael Perez/Associated Press
item.media:description: DeSean Jackson, a Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver, said on Instagram on Tuesday that he “really didn’t realize what this passage was saying.”

item.title: They Can’t Stomach Trump. They’re Sufficiently Comfortable With Biden.
item.description: Some voters who disliked both nominees in 2016 chose a third-party candidate instead. Now, many of them are shunning President Trump and are ready to back Joe Biden.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has an overwhelming advantage over President Trump among voters who have unfavorable views of both candidates.

item.title: Jaime Harrison's Fund-Raising Total Adds to Democrats' Impressive Senate Hauls
item.description: Mr. Harrison raised nearly $14 million as he tries to unseat Lindsey Graham in South Carolina, and Ms. McGrath, who is challenging Mitch McConnell in Kentucky, brought in $17.4 million.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan and Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Sean Rayford/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jaime Harrison during a Martin Luther King Jr. Day event in Columbia, S.C., in January. Mr. Harrison, who outraised Senator Lindsey Graham in the first quarter of the year, nearly doubled his haul in the second quarter.

item.title: Mary Trump’s Book Accuses the President of Embracing ‘Cheating as a Way of Life’
item.description: The president’s niece, Mary L. Trump, is the first to break ranks with the family and release a tell-all memoir.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.category: Too Much And Never Enough: How My Family Created the World's Most Dangerous Man (Book)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has long been estranged from his niece, Mary L. Trump.

item.title: Travel Restrictions on Americans Erode a Sense of Passport Privilege
item.description: As countries across the world ease coronavirus restrictions but block American travelers, a long-held sense that the U.S. passport was a golden ticket is losing its luster.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Johannes Eisele/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers, many wearing masks, line up at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York.

item.title: In the Twin Cities’ Robust Dining Scene, Few Black-Owned Businesses
item.description: In the wake of George Floyd’s killing, chefs and restaurateurs are looking for ways to fix the racial imbalance.
item.dc:creator: Mecca Bos
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before it closed last October, Jared Brewington’s restaurant Funky Grits was across the street from where George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis.

item.title: A Black-Owned Distillery in Minneapolis Pushes Forward
item.description: From the pandemic to protests to arson, Du Nord Craft Spirits has dealt with repeated turmoil and emerged with a new purpose.
item.dc:creator: Robert Simonson
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chris and Shanelle Montana at Du Nord Craft Spirits, which has been closed since its building burned on May 29.

item.title: Two Chefs Moved to Rural Minnesota to Expand on Their Mission of Racial Justice
item.description: Mateo Mackbee and Erin Lucas left Minneapolis for a small central Minnesota community, where they are using their restaurant, bakery and farm to promote diversity and teach children about food.
item.dc:creator: Brett Anderson
item.media:credit: Andrea Ellen Reed for The New York Times
item.media:description: Erin Lucas and Mateo Mackbee on a farm they’re building in central Minnesota, where they also run a restaurant, bakery and nonprofit.

item.title: Hogan, Maryland Governor, Plans Book Tour as He Eyes 2024 White House Run
item.description: Larry Hogan, the Republican governor of a solidly Democratic state, who has drawn attention for his criticism of President Trump’s coronavirus response, writes at length about the experience.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland in Annapolis in April.

item.title: L.A. School Police Budget Cuts: Demonstrators Demanded Defunding
item.description: The former chief called the decision “potentially life-threatening” for students and staff members.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Will Wright
item.media:credit: Marcio Jose Sanchez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanded the defunding of the Los Angeles school district police outside of the school board headquarters on June 23.

item.title: Anthony Fauci Paints a Dire Picture of the Coronavirus Epidemic
item.description: A virus testing crisis grows, and Trump tries out new dog whistles: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Why Isn’t the ‘Southern Strategy’ Working?
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Rory Doyle/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Highway Safety Patrol Honor Guard retire the state flag outside the capitol building in Jackson, Miss. last week.

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: U.S. and Global News
item.description: President Trump made it official: The U.S. is pulling out of the World Health Organization. President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, who has been dismissive of virus precautions, has tested positive.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Susan Collins Battles for Survival in Maine
item.description: The fourth-term Republican is staring down a better-funded challenger and national headwinds, all while campaigning amid coronavirus restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, leading a small Fourth of July parade in Lubec, Maine.

item.title: Nurses Who Battled Virus in New York Confront Friends Back Home Who Say It’s a Hoax
item.description: After aiding coronavirus patients in New York City, nurses face relatives and friends who refuse to wear masks or don’t believe the virus is real.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “When someone tells me that they don’t believe the virus is real, it’s an insult,” said Olumide Peter Kolade, a nurse from California who came to work in New York City. “I take it personally.”

item.title: 2020 N.J. and Delaware Primary Elections: What to Watch For
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s home state is holding a presidential primary, and New Jersey has a full slate of congressional primaries on tap in an election that will be held mostly by mail.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Erica Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stickers are handed out to voters at Paramus High School in Paramus, NJ.
